facts: Wrote the first computer algorithm for Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine in 1843
Daughter of poet Lord Byron, combined mathematical genius with poetic imagination
Recognized that computers could go beyond pure calculation to create music and art
Her 'Note G' contained the first published computer program, calculating Bernoulli numbers
Studied advanced mathematics despite limited formal education opportunities for women
Envisioned computers as general-purpose machines, not just number calculators
Collaborated with Babbage on mechanical computing concepts that were century ahead of their time
Died young at 36 from uterine cancer, but her vision laid groundwork for modern computing
